column2: In which course are you enrolled?
column3: Course design [The assigned readings have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column4: Course design [The RStudio primers have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column5: Course design [The Team Activities have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column6: Course design [The Learning Journals have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column7: Course design [The online class sessions have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column8: Course design [The Projects have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column9: Course design [The Applications have helped me meet the Learning Targets.]
column10: Course design [The Blackboard course site is organized in a way that helps me to effectively navigate the course materials.]
column11: Instructor [The instructor is genuinely interested in my understanding.]
column13: Instructor [The instructor is available for extra help when needed.]
column14: What as been the best aspect of *this course* so far, and why?
column15: If there was one thing about *this course* that you would change, what would it be, and why?
column16: What is one thing that *you* can do differently to improve your learning? Explain how you plan to do this.
column17: Optional: Provide any additional comments that you feel that were not addressed by the above items or that you wish to expand upon here.

column14: I think the best aspect so far has been the effectiveness of teaching the material. I think for programming, a bunch of demonstrations/lectures isn't very effective, but this course's set up of reading/doing primers before class and then practice has been really good in my opinion.
column15: I think the learning journals are far too frequent. Honestly it feels like I'm stretching for content a lot because there are only two classes a week. I feel like the class is pretty time consuming with everything else, and the learning journals are just another thing. I definitely understand that they are useful and its good to reflect on what we've learned, I just think too many are required.
column16: I think one thing I can do better is utilizing more of the tidyverse content and cheatsheets. Also, sometimes in the team activities I may not do a good enough job of understanding everything going on, I just follow the instructions. So I could slow down a bit and try to learn it a bit better, but that is kind of hard in a group setting trying not too get too far behind.
column17: Overall, I really like this course and I feel like I'm learning a lot. However, I think the application from this weekend was pretty rough. I hope that those get better as we move forward. I understand they are supposed to be challenging and prove what we know, but it took a **very** long time and a lot of effort. Maybe having a bit more time to work on them or toning down the difficulty a bit would be helpful. I am definitely spending way more than 6 hours outside of class on coursework, which concerns me going forward because there are still a lot of projects left and more applications.

column14: The best aspect of this course is the RStudio Primers because they teach me a lot about what I can do with R.
column15: I would change the need for so many types of assignments. It's kind of hard to keep up with learning journals, preparations, follow ups, activities, projects, applications, and then the videos/meetings with you.
column16: I really don't know. I take my time and get everything done in advance. I also work ahead on activities (my whole group does) so we have a better chance of actually finishing it in class. I still am not doing how I would expect for the amount of work I put into this class.

column14: I like the organization of the course work: prep, activity, project/assessment. This is how I tend to learn. Read/see how its done, practice doing it myself, assess.
column15: The learning Journals. I do not find these useful for my learning, especially without specific prompts/I have no idea what benefit they provide me in this course.  I would also remove the team activity merging because I prefer to be responsible for my own work.
column16: Ask more questions. I tend to search for answers on my own for far too long before asking for help.
column17: The time spent on this course in order to maybe get an A is too much or at least very unexpected given it is a 3 credit course. Additionally, it would be helpful to have prep for the week rather than by day or preps posted earlier. Having roughly 24hours to complete in-class work and the prep is not a lot of time for students who have responsibilities outside of this course.

column14: The useful and straightforward RStudio primers.
column15: It would be nice if there was one activity per week instead of 2. So that groups have time to work on it and not stress over deadlines.
column16: Prioritize this class over my other ones. I'm realizing that this class requires a lot of outside class time. I'll open up my schedule to work on this class every day.
column17: Altogether, I feel like we have too much homework. I appreciate that we can revise things. However, I find it hard to put my 100% effort into my other classes when this class is taking most of my focus. Not to be dramatic, but I'm worried about my mental health for the rest of the semester. Online classes (specifically this one) are not easy during a pandemic.

column14: The group assignments, because we're doing them in class, so we don't have to find some time outside of class to meet (which is the worst part of group work), and also because we don't have to decide parts for each person to do like most group work I've been a part of in the past.
column15: I think I'd prefer the prep work to be due before the start of class rather than the night before (though this is because my schedule is really weird and I do most of my homework between midnight and 4am).
column16: I feel like there isn't much more I can do to improve my learning, though I did somehow accidently cross off Prep 8 from my assignment list thing that I keep without actually doing it, which I should make sure to not do again.

column14: I think the best part of the course so far is the studio primer activities which seem to help. The activities during class would be a second.
column15: Probably the amount of time working with groups. Me and my group barely talk to each other during class time and so they don't help.
column16: I think the biggest thing would be to find some sort of suppliment material to work off of. There are things that we do in projects and applications that I don't seem to get.
column17: I feel like during certain assignments and such that we are asked to do things that we haven't been taught or that need a lot better descriptions. For example, during the last application, we were required to use the paste0 function which we hadn't done before and after reading the documentation provided by R help command, it was still unclear how it should be used.

column14: The self-discovery and proficiency-style learning in the course allow me to be flexible in my learning, sometimes discovering functions and topics not explicitly covered in the preparations or syllabus.
column15: I'd rather have this course in person. But then again, I'd rather have every course in person. For how this course had to be presented because of the pandemic, it is an excellent course. I have no negative or constructive comments to make.
column16: I can schedule a time to do my classwork. With how much flexibility is offered to me, I tend to be a little too flexible in how I get work done, sometimes rushing it or submitting it last-minute.

column14: The group work. It has helped me understand the concepts and learn better. They're always there to answer questions and provide help if I need it.
column15: Some of the final grading requirements (such as what is expected for project and learning targets) are unclear to me. I'm not sure if videos and additional work is expected.
column16: Keep up to date on my Learning Journals. I plan to set reminders to complete them.

column14: I think the primers and, in class and outside classroom meetings have really benefitted the most in understanding and completing the activities.
column15: Probably more opportunities to receive help on activities and projects further in the week.
column16: communicate with my group more to receive help on any questions in the activities. Make sure I clearly communicate the problem I'm having in the activity so they can easily respond with an answer.

column14: Have learned a lot by doing each of the activities and reading
column15: There is one too many assignments to have prepared for each class. If I didn't know how many credits this class was worth and I had to guess, I would say 5 rather than 3.
column16: Not rushing though the primers and readings for the sake of time allocation.

column14: The content has all been great. The book is very good, and the primers and activities supply good practice to go along with the readings.
column15: The first thing I would change would be lowering the learning journal requirement. I am an A student, but I find that I may not be able to get an A in this class solely because of the insane amount of learning journals we are supposed to do. I do not think it should have such a heavy weight on our grade. If we have 2 preparations/week, I think it would make sense to require 2 learning journals/week to get reach an A.
column16: I think I'm learning a lot, and I understand the material, so I do not have anything I'd change.
column17:
I first typed all of this under the question asking what one thing we'd change about the course. Seeing this section, I think it's a more appropriate place to put it:

It's a lot. Activities, preparations, learning journals, applications, projects. I feel that the actual material in this class is not difficult, but I find it very hard to find the time to do everything. This is coming from someone with a full time job, but this course is required for my degree and my degree is supposed to be designed for working professionals. A lot of my time in the activities is helping my group members, so those take up even more time given we need to merge our work when we all finish. I don't know if groups are appropriate for this class - I get along with my group well, but I feel like I'm a tutor for a class I'm currently enrolled in. In addition, only having one day to complete a preparation and follow-up between classes isn't great, and having applications and projects seems redundant. I really do enjoy the material that we are learning in this class. It just seems like a lot of repetitive busy work.

column14: the best aspect is that the resources are readily available for the students
column15: i would find a way to get rid of github. most of the issues my group and i have had have been directly related to github rather than learning r
column16: spend more time to learn the information

column14: A combo of the primers and group activities
column15: The layout of the Applications. I replicated the table exactly minus having used knittr since it wasn't mentioned that we needed to use the knittr package.
column16: If I had more time, I would ensure I understand everything that we're covering as we cover it. Sadly I don't have the time so I'm hoping to understand it from the primers/readings.
column17: The primers and readings sometimes overlap and it's redundant to do both (unless the student doesn't have any experience coding or using R). Also a bit more guidance/explicitly stating what you want in the applications would be an immense help and save time.

column14: The class sessions because we are able to work with our group to learn together and Professor Dykes is available to help when needed.
column15: The grading scales because they are confusing
column16: Take notes while doing the RStudio Primers to have a "cheat sheet" to use when working on activities.

column14: I think the best part would be the rstudio cloud primers I think they give a good start and understanding
column15: All the group work because sometimes it is like you are doing the work by yourself
column16: I think using over sources for help online to really firm up some content

column14: Instead of starting out slow with basics, we dove straight into r and how to use it effectively while working with datasets. I like this part the most because it is a higher level course, and so many minor details can be picked up as you go, instead of dedicating large amounts of class time on basic concepts for statistical coding.
column15: At some points, the in-class coursework is slightly tedious/long, yet at the same time this is an upper level course so that is to be expected. If it is possible to slightly consolidate the coding we do in class, while not compromising too much of our time with other assignments out of class and not missing any content, then that would be perfect. Yet, this could be too much to ask for depending on how adaptable the content/module schedule is. Also, I have a tough time finding the motivation to complete the learning journals since I am preoccupied with other assignments in this class.
column16: I have been neglecting the course journals, unfortunately. On top of other class assignments and other courses, it can be difficult to remember to complete them.
column17: I hope this all helps, and thank you for giving us this opportunity to express ourselves! This is the first time a professor has been very open and direct with the course plan. Good thinking!

column14: The team activities. Not only has it allowed me to meet a couple of new people, but it has been nice being able to work together and share ideas with my teammates.
column15: Being able to utilize more resources for the applications. The reason being that in the real world you would want to use any resource necessary in order to get the job done, and so I think that should be considered here for the applications.
column16: I think just spending more time with the material will help.

column14: The group work is nice to work together and understand concepts
column15: The work load is a lot for three credits, the learning journals require a lot to get an A and the grading is confusing. The learning targets have a lot of different aspects to get an A and it is a little confusing/daunting looking at the syllabus and trying to figure out everything we need to do to get an A.
column16: I could map out the course for myself and make a list/plan on what I need to accomplish each week and over the semester.

column14: Working through examples has been the best aspect of the course.
column15: The group work is helpful, but I would like more instruction through specifics when functions get more difficult. Such as pivot as it is not in the coursework.
column16: Try to find more examples to go through the course work. The beginning was easy, but as things progress and get more complex it gets confusing for me.

column14: I enjoy learning R language and applying it.
column15: I feel there is more work than learning accomplished; it is difficult to work in groups and I feel pressure and anxiety when class time is strictly group work which I feel distracts from learning
column16: Use the materials provided; continue to navigate where to find information needed
column17: I feel having only group works makes the question time in the beginning of class rushed;  I'm disappointed recordings of class sessions haven't been made available, as I feel it would be valuable to be able to watch what occurs when you are meeting with individual groups.

column14: I really like working as a team to work through the activities. It is a really immersive experience and helps reinforce the knowledge I'm learning in the book and the primers.
column15: I don't love the learning journals. I don't think I'm getting very much from them and it is tedious more than helpful.
column16: I could re-read the chapters now that I have more of an understanding of the language.

column14: Especially because this class is online, I really appreciate the group aspect of this class. It is nice to have other students to turn to when I struggle with something.
column15: The workload is so much. It has been a serious struggle to try and keep up with at times. I appreciate that it is so structured and your attempt to keep up with the "standard" practice, but nothing about this semester is standard. The prep and follow up that we must complete between 7:15pm Monday and midnight on Tuesday is especially difficult.
column16: I could block out more time for reading the chapters. I find it difficult to complete the assignments at times because it feels as if I don't fully understand the "language." It has been hard to try to teach myself as someone with very limited coding experience.

column14: Team activities. It is helpful to work and problem-solve together.
column15: I would like to have more time to complete an application.
column16: Write more journal entries, especially on how I could apply the material to my own examples.

column14: The best aspect ate the activities and primers. Activities help me learn the concept in a effective way. Primers give an outline before getting into the actual activity
column15: Instead of two classes a week It would be better if we a one class with a duration of 3 hours
column16: For now I think I'm in the right direction.
